poem:
Final Destination in Technicolor

Death's invisible hand  
dances on celluloid streets,  
weaving a tapestry  
of almosts—  
lives snatched back,  
borrowed moments  
ripple like silk.  
Light flickers,  
projector hums,  
theater of near-endings  
breathes through  
time's narrow corridor,  
while we sit,  
hearts tethered  
to the thread,  
unraveling fate's encore  
in shadowed silence.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Final Destination to Long Bright River: a complete guide to this week’s entertainment Going out: Cinema Final Destination: BloodlinesOut nowFunctioning like a sort of extreme version of You’ve Been Framed, this is the premier horror franchise dedicated to giving you intrusive thoughts about horrible accidents. Of course, they aren’t actually accidents, but Death himself, stalking those snatched from his grasp via handy premonitions. Not for the faint of stomach.E.1027: Eileen Gray and the House by". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
